column3: Kolya ran out of the room, the boys followed him.

column3: At last Alyosha too went out.

column2: Let them weep, he said to Kolya, "it's no use trying to comfort them just now.
column3: Let them weep, he said to Kolya, "it's no use trying to comfort them just now.

column2: Let us wait a minute and then go back."
column3: Let us wait a minute and then go back."

column2: No, it's no use, it's awful, Kolya assented.
column3: No, it's no use, it's awful, Kolya assented.

column2: Do you know, Karamazov, he dropped his voice so that no one could hear them, "I feel dreadfully sad, and if it were only possible to bring him back, I'd give anything in the world to do it."
column3: Do you know, Karamazov, he dropped his voice so that no one could hear them, "I feel dreadfully sad, and if it were only possible to bring him back, I'd give anything in the world to do it."

column2: Ah, so would I, said Alyosha.
column3: Ah, so would I, said Alyosha.

column2: What do you think, Karamazov?	What do you think, Karamazov?
column3: true

column2: Had we better come back here to-night? He'll be drunk, you know."
column3: Had we better come back here to night? He'll be drunk, you know."

column2: Perhaps he will.	Perhaps he will.
column3: true

column2: Let us come together, you and I, that will be enough, to spend an hour with them, with the mother and Nina.
column3: Let us come together, you and I, that will be enough, to spend an hour with them, with the mother and Nina.

column2: If we all come together we shall remind them of everything again," Alyosha suggested.
column3: If we all come together we shall remind them of everything again," Alyosha suggested.

column2: The landlady is laying the table for them now--there'll be a funeral dinner or something, the priest is coming; shall we go back to it, Karamazov?
column3: The landlady is laying the table for them now-there'll be a funeral dinner or something, the priest is coming; shall we go back to it, Karamazov?

column2: Of course, said Alyosha.
column3: Of course, said Alyosha.

column2: It's all so strange, Karamazov, such sorrow and then pancakes after it, it all seems so unnatural in our religion.
column3: It's all so strange, Karamazov, such sorrow and then pancakes after it, it all seems so unnatural in our religion.

column2: They are going to have salmon, too, the boy who had discovered about Troy observed in a loud voice.
column3: They are going to have salmon, too, the boy who had discovered about Troy observed in a loud voice.

column2: I beg you most earnestly, Kartashov, not to interrupt again with your idiotic remarks, especially when one is not talking to you and doesn't care to know whether you exist or not! Kolya snapped out irritably.
column3: I beg you most earnestly, Kartashov, not to interrupt again with your idiotic remarks, especially when one is not talking to you and doesn't care to know whether you exist or not! Kolya snapped out irritably.

column2: The boy flushed crimson but did not dare to reply.
column3: The boy flushed crimson but did not dare to reply.

column2: Meantime they were strolling slowly along the path and suddenly Smurov exclaimed:
column3: Meantime they were strolling slowly along the path and suddenly Smurov exclaimed:

column2: There's Ilusha's stone, under which they wanted to bury him.
column3: There's Ilusha's stone, under which they wanted to bury him.

column2: They all stood still by the big stone.
column3: They all stood still by the big stone.

column2: Alyosha looked and the whole picture of what Snegiryov had described to him that day, how Ilusha, weeping and hugging his father, had cried, "Father, father, how he insulted you," rose at once before his imagination.
column3: Alyosha looked and the whole picture of what Snegiryov had described to him that day, how Ilusha, weeping and hugging his father, had cried, "Father, father, how he insulted you," rose at once before his imagination.

column2: A sudden impulse seemed to come into his soul.
column3: A sudden impulse seemed to come into his soul.

column2: With a serious and earnest expression he looked from one to another of the bright, pleasant faces of Ilusha's schoolfellows, and suddenly said to them:
column3: With a serious and earnest expression he looked from one to another of the bright, pleasant faces of Ilusha's schoolfellows, and suddenly said to them:

column2: Boys, I should like to say one word to you, here at this place.
column3: Boys, I should like to say one word to you, here at this place.

column2: The boys stood round him and at once bent attentive and expectant eyes upon him.
column3: The boys stood round him and at once bent attentive and expectant eyes upon him.

column2: Boys, we shall soon part.	Boys, we shall soon part.
column3: true

column2: I shall be for some time with my two brothers, of whom one is going to Siberia and the other is lying at death's door. But soon I shall leave this town, perhaps for a long time, so we shall part.
column3: I shall be for some time with my two brothers, of whom one is going to Siberia and the other is lying at death's door. But soon I shall leave this town, perhaps for a long time, so we shall part.

column2: Let us make a compact here, at Ilusha's stone, that we will never forget Ilusha and one another.
column3: Let us make a compact here, at Ilusha's stone, that we will never forget Ilusha and one another.

column2: And whatever happens to us later in life, if we don't meet for twenty years afterwards, let us always remember how we buried the poor boy at whom we once threw stones, do you remember, by the bridge?
column3: And whatever happens to us later in life, if we don't meet for twenty years afterwards, let us always remember how we buried the poor boy at whom we once threw stones, do you remember, by the bridge?

column2: and afterwards we all grew so fond of him.
column3: and afterwards we all grew so fond of him.

column2: He was a fine boy, a kind-hearted, brave boy, he felt for his father's honor and resented the cruel insult to him and stood up for him.
column3: He was a fine boy, a kind hearted, brave boy, he felt for his father's honor and resented the cruel insult to him and stood up for him.

column2: And so in the first place, we will remember him, boys, all our lives.
column3: And so in the first place, we will remember him, boys, all our lives.

column2: And even if we are occupied with most important things, if we attain to honor or fall into great misfortune--still let us remember how good it was once here, when we were all together, united by a good and kind feeling which made us, for the time we were loving that poor boy, better perhaps than we are.
column3: And even if we are occupied with most important things, if we attain to honor or fall into great misfortune-still let us remember how good it was once here, when we were all together, united by a good and kind feeling which made us, for the time we were loving that poor boy, better perhaps than we are.

column2: My little doves--let me call you so, for you are very like them, those pretty blue birds, at this minute as I look at your good dear faces.
column3: My little doves-let me call you so, for you are very like them, those pretty blue birds, at this minute as I look at your good dear faces.

column2: My dear children, perhaps you won't understand what I am saying to you, because I often speak very unintelligibly, but you'll remember it all the same and will agree with my words some time.
column3: My dear children, perhaps you won't understand what I am saying to you, because I often speak very unintelligibly, but you'll remember it all the same and will agree with my words some time.

column2: You must know that there is nothing higher and stronger and more wholesome and good for life in the future than some good memory, especially a memory of childhood, of home.
column3: You must know that there is nothing higher and stronger and more wholesome and good for life in the future than some good memory, especially a memory of childhood, of home.

column2: People talk to you a great deal about your education, but some good, sacred memory, preserved from childhood, is perhaps the best education.
column3: People talk to you a great deal about your education, but some good, sacred memory, preserved from childhood, is perhaps the best education.

column2: If a man carries many such memories with him into life, he is safe to the end of his days, and if one has only one good memory left in one's heart, even that may sometime be the means of saving us.
column3: If a man carries many such memories with him into life, he is safe to the end of his days, and if one has only one good memory left in one's heart, even that may sometime be the means of saving us.

column2: Perhaps we may even grow wicked later on, may be unable to refrain from a bad action, may laugh at men's tears and at those people who say as Kolya did just now, 'I want to suffer for all men,' and may even jeer spitefully at such people.
column3: Perhaps we may even grow wicked later on, may be unable to refrain from a bad action, may laugh at men's tears and at those people who say as Kolya did just now, 'I want to suffer for all men,' and may even jeer spitefully at such people.

column2: But however bad we may become--which God forbid--yet, when we recall how we buried Ilusha, how we loved him in his last days, and how we have been talking like friends all together, at this stone, the cruelest and most mocking of us--if we do become so--will not dare to laugh inwardly at having been kind and good at this moment!
column3: But however bad we may become-which God forbid-yet, when we recall how we buried Ilusha, how we loved him in his last days, and how we have been talking like friends all together, at this stone, the cruelest and most mocking of us-if we do become so-will not dare to laugh inwardly at having been kind and good at this moment!

column2: What's more, perhaps, that one memory may keep him from great evil and he will reflect and say, 'Yes, I was good and brave and honest then!' Let him laugh to himself, that's no matter, a man often laughs at what's good and kind.
column3: What's more, perhaps, that one memory may keep him from great evil and he will reflect and say, 'Yes, I was good and brave and honest then!' Let him laugh to himself, that's no matter, a man often laughs at what's good and kind.

column2: That's only from thoughtlessness.
column3: That's only from thoughtlessness.

column2: But I assure you, boys, that as he laughs he will say at once in his heart, 'No, I do wrong to laugh, for that's not a thing to laugh at.' "
column3: But I assure you, boys, that as he laughs he will say at once in his heart, 'No, I do wrong to laugh, for that's not a thing to laugh at.' "

column2: That will be so, I understand you, Karamazov! cried Kolya, with flashing eyes.
column3: That will be so, I understand you, Karamazov! cried Kolya, with flashing eyes.

column2: The boys were excited and they, too, wanted to say something, but they restrained themselves, looking with intentness and emotion at the speaker.
column3: The boys were excited and they, too, wanted to say something, but they restrained themselves, looking with intentness and emotion at the speaker.

column2: I say this in case we become bad, Alyosha went on, "but there's no reason why we should become bad, is there, boys?
column3: I say this in case we become bad, Alyosha went on, "but there's no reason why we should become bad, is there, boys?

column2: Let us be, first and above all, kind, then honest and then let us never forget each other!
column3: Let us be, first and above all, kind, then honest and then let us never forget each other!

column2: I say that again.
column3: I say that again.

column2: I give you my word for my part that I'll never forget one of you.
column3: I give you my word for my part that I'll never forget one of you.

column2: Every face looking at me now I shall remember even for thirty years.
column3: Every face looking at me now I shall remember even for thirty years.

column2: Just now Kolya said to Kartashov that we did not care to know whether he exists or not.
column3: Just now Kolya said to Kartashov that we did not care to know whether he exists or not.

column2: But I cannot forget that Kartashov exists and that he is not blushing now as he did when he discovered the founders of Troy, but is looking at me with his jolly, kind, dear little eyes.
column3: But I cannot forget that Kartashov exists and that he is not blushing now as he did when he discovered the founders of Troy, but is looking at me with his jolly, kind, dear little eyes.

column2: Boys, my dear boys, let us all be generous and brave like Ilusha, clever, brave and generous like Kolya (though he will be ever so much cleverer when he is grown up), and let us all be as modest, as clever and sweet as Kartashov.
column3: Boys, my dear boys, let us all be generous and brave like Ilusha, clever, brave and generous like Kolya (though he will be ever so much cleverer when he is grown up), and let us all be as modest, as clever and sweet as Kartashov.

column2: But why am I talking about those two?
column3: But why am I talking about those two?

column2: You are all dear to me, boys, from this day forth, I have a place in my heart for you all, and I beg you to keep a place in your hearts for me!
column3: You are all dear to me, boys, from this day forth, I have a place in my heart for you all, and I beg you to keep a place in your hearts for me!

column2: Well, and who has united us in this kind, good feeling which we shall remember and intend to remember all our lives?
column3: Well, and who has united us in this kind, good feeling which we shall remember and intend to remember all our lives?

column2: Who, if not Ilusha, the good boy, the dear boy, precious to us for ever!
column3: Who, if not Ilusha, the good boy, the dear boy, precious to us for ever!

column2: Let us never forget him.
column3: Let us never forget him.

column2: May his memory live for ever in our hearts from this time forth!"
column3: May his memory live for ever in our hearts from this time forth!"

column2: Yes, yes, for ever, for ever! the boys cried in their ringing voices, with softened faces.
column3: Yes, yes, for ever, for ever! the boys cried in their ringing voices, with softened faces.

column2: Let us remember his face and his clothes and his poor little boots, his coffin and his unhappy, sinful father, and how boldly he stood up for him alone against the whole school.
column3: Let us remember his face and his clothes and his poor little boots, his coffin and his unhappy, sinful father, and how boldly he stood up for him alone against the whole school.

column2: We will remember, we will remember, cried the boys.
column3: We will remember, we will remember, cried the boys.

column2: He was brave, he was good!
column3: He was brave, he was good!

column2: Ah, how I loved him! exclaimed Kolya.
column3: Ah, how I loved him! exclaimed Kolya.

column2: Ah, children, ah, dear friends, don't be afraid of life!	Ah, children, ah, dear friends, don't be afraid of life!
column3: false

column2: How good life is when one does something good and just!"
column3: How good life is when one does something good and just!"

column2: Yes, yes, the boys repeated enthusiastically.
column3: Yes, yes, the boys repeated enthusiastically.

column2: Karamazov, we love you! a voice, probably Kartashov's, cried impulsively.
column3: Karamazov, we love you! a voice, probably Kartashov's, cried impulsively.

column2: We love you, we love you! they all caught it up.
column3: We love you, we love you! they all caught it up.

column2: There were tears in the eyes of many of them.
column3: There were tears in the eyes of many of them.

column2: Hurrah for Karamazov! Kolya shouted ecstatically.
column3: Hurrah for Karamazov! Kolya shouted ecstatically.

column2: And may the dead boy's memory live for ever! Alyosha added again with feeling.
column3: And may the dead boy's memory live for ever! Alyosha added again with feeling.

column2: For ever! the boys chimed in again.
column3: For ever! the boys chimed in again.

column2: Karamazov, cried Kolya, "can it be true what's taught us in religion, that we shall all rise again from the dead and shall live and see each other again, all, Ilusha too?"
column3: Karamazov, cried Kolya, "can it be true what's taught us in religion, that we shall all rise again from the dead and shall live and see each other again, all, Ilusha too?"

column2: Certainly we shall all rise again, certainly we shall see each other and shall tell each other with joy and gladness all that has happened! Alyosha answered, half laughing, half enthusiastic.
column3: Certainly we shall all rise again, certainly we shall see each other and shall tell each other with joy and gladness all that has happened! Alyosha answered, half laughing, half enthusiastic.

column2: Ah, how splendid it will be! broke from Kolya.
column3: Ah, how splendid it will be! broke from Kolya.

column2: Well, now we will finish talking and go to his funeral dinner.	Well, now we will finish talking and go to his funeral dinner.
column3: true

column2: Don't be put out at our eating pancakes--it's a very old custom and there's something nice in that!" laughed Alyosha.
column3: Don't be put out at our eating pancakes-it's a very old custom and there's something nice in that!" laughed Alyosha.

column2: Well, let us go!	Well, let us go!
column3: true

column2: And now we go hand in hand."
column3: And now we go hand in hand."

column2: And always so, all our lives hand in hand!	And always so, all our lives hand in hand!
column3: false

column2: Hurrah for Karamazov!" Kolya cried once more rapturously, and once more the boys took up his exclamation: "Hurrah for Karamazov!"
column3: Hurrah for Karamazov!" Kolya cried once more rapturously, and once more the boys took up his exclamation: "Hurrah for Karamazov!"

column2: THE END
column3: THE END
